oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Frierson-Voorhies Cemetery: Unmarked headstone
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Eatherly, Brad, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of a small unmarked headstone.

The Frierson-Voorhies Cemetery is located in a section of Brentwood, Tennessee that was once known as the Hardscuffle Community. The African-American community of Hardscuffle extended along what is now Church Street East from Wilson Pike to Edmondson Road. Hardscuffle was formed a couple of years after the Civil War ended when freed slaves began purchasing property along what was then known as Hardscuffle Road. About fifty African-American families ultimately lived in the community. The community also supported three churches, two schools, and a baseball field. The property where the cemetery is located used to be owned by Hardscuffle community members Wilbur and Katherine Hayes. The community's property owners were offered about $150,000 in the 1960s when Interstate 65 was being constructed. Mt. Lebanon Missionary Baptist Church and Brooks Memorial Methodist Church were two of the churches that served Hardscuffle.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American cemeteries; Cemeteries; Sepulchral monuments
